This game is great, even though I don't play that ranked, and I have long periods when I don't play at all, I still come back to his game once in a while, make my own 4v4 lobby and play a couple of matches.
Upsides:
1. Very unique and interesting concept, there are barely any games like this
2. The multiplayer is very fun to play
3. The campains (especially high seas) are interesting
4. Very high skill ceiling
5. The community isn't toxic at all, and you can have some nice conversations in the in-game chat.
6. The game is being constantly supported, and they release dlcs regularly
7. The developers listen to player feedback, for example, after the community expressed desire for ship battles, they came up with an entire new dlc which adds just that (please do note, high seas is a wonderful dlc, and if you ever want do buy this game you should also buy high seas)
8. 4v4 maps are a whole lot of fun, as they're a lot less stressful than 1v1 or 2v2 (the game also has 3v3 but there's only a couple of maps for that)
9. Extensive modding and mapping community
Some things I don't like about this game:
1. Most gamemodes aside from normal 4v4  battles (for example that capture point thing that Moonshot introduced) are kind of unrefinded, and aren't very fun to play
2. Some campaigns have large flaws and there are large difficulty spikes in all of them. 
3. Overall, the campaign for the base game could get an upgrade. It doesn't include the tons of guns free expansion, which makes for a very lackluster variety of weapons (like there are only 10 or so weapons INCLUDING UPGRADES) and the level designs get somewhat boring at some point
4. Despite the weapon balance being great, some weapons are a bit too weak and aren't used that often (for example I never see shotguns actually get used that often, same with 20mm cannons which deal pitiful damage)
5. Anti-air is sometimes a chore, and missiles can be frustrating to counter
6. The game can be really stressful
7. The moonshot dlc, despite adding some more depth to the game, was kinda dissapointing in its lack of content and boring campaign
8. Winning multiplayer battles relies a lot on the player being able to follow certain early-game schemes to build up their forts and on gaining better weapons as fast as possible, 
Despite all the flaws, the game is great and you should definitely buy it.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

This game is just a lot of fun. Before buying and playing it, I watched some gaming videos on YouTube and that's what convinced me to play it myself. The upgrading of elements is well done, and it has a wide variety of achievements.

It's quite the fun game as I love RTS games (I've played StarCraft since I was like 5 :P). It's also pretty unique when it comes to RTS games, as most of them, especially ones with roots in the 90's, are top-down or isometric view games where you control units to move around maps while expanding your base for resource locations and simultaneously build up an army. Instead, Forts is a stationary one, which although conceptually may seem quite a bit more boring, it strangely isn't. Maybe it's the physics element to it that makes it satisfying to hit a weak spot and see as your enemy's base crumbles, or maybe it's something else, I'm not sure. Some things I would complain about though is that unit/weapon selection, especially when it comes to control grouping, isn't as intuitive as in other games (such as in StarCraft) which could be improved on, and the fact that the auto Anti-Air AI is kind of stupid, but other than that, its a great game, and I probably would recommend to people who generally enjoy RTS games, its just good fun ig.

Introduction:
In the vast landscape of indie gaming, Forts 2017, developed by EarthWork Games, emerges as a beacon of strategic ingenuity and explosive combat. As players delve into the dynamic fusion of base-building and real-time battles, they find themselves navigating a virtual battlefield where the height of their fortress mirrors the depth of their tactical prowess. This review embarks on an in-depth exploration of Forts, dissecting its gameplay dynamics, visual aesthetics, room for improvement, community engagement, and the enduring appeal that positions it as a noteworthy entry in the strategy gaming realm.

Gameplay Dynamics:
At its core, Forts presents players with a unique challenge: construct an impregnable fortress armed with an arsenal of weapons, each more devastating than the last. The game's construction mechanics seamlessly blend intuition with intricacy, allowing players to craft fortresses that are both aesthetically impressive and strategically sound. The inclusion of a physics engine adds a layer of realism, forcing players to consider structural stability in the midst of explosive chaos. This balance of creativity and strategy serves as the game's cornerstone, setting it apart from traditional strategy titles.

In the single-player campaign, Forts leads players through a series of progressively challenging scenarios, introducing them to an array of weapons and tactics. However, the true brilliance of Forts manifests in its multiplayer mode. Engaging in battles of wits and firepower with friends or online opponents transforms the experience into a dynamic, unpredictable symphony of destruction. Coordinating attacks, adapting to enemy strategies, and witnessing meticulously crafted fortresses crumble under relentless assaults create moments of sheer satisfaction and adrenaline-pumping excitement.

Visually, Forts embraces a charming and cartoonish aesthetic that complements its lighthearted and approachable nature. While the game doesn't strive for photorealism, it effectively conveys the chaos of battle and the destructive power of its diverse arsenal. The soundtrack, though not particularly groundbreaking, provides a fitting backdrop to the gameplay, enhancing the overall experience without overshadowing the on-screen action.

Room for Improvement:
While Forts excels in many aspects, there is room for improvement. The game's mission objectives and environments, while entertaining, can exhibit a degree of repetitiveness over extended play sessions. More variety in challenges and landscapes could have injected additional depth into the gameplay and prolonged overall engagement. However, it's crucial to note that the core mechanics and the sheer joy of watching carefully constructed fortresses crumble under the weight of battle mitigate this drawback to a considerable extent.

Community Engagement:
Forts has earned commendable support from its developers, evident in regular updates and additional content that enrich the gaming experience. The modding community has played a pivotal role in extending the game's lifespan and replayability. This collaborative effort between developers and players ensures that Forts remains a dynamic and evolving entity in the gaming landscape.

The multiplayer community, in particular, adds a vibrant layer to Forts' longevity. Engaging with fellow players in a thriving online ecosystem, sharing strategies, and witnessing the creative approaches others bring to the battlefield contribute significantly to the game's enduring appeal.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Forts 2017 offers a delightful and distinctive gaming experience that successfully marries strategic depth with explosive real-time action. Its innovative take on base-building, coupled with the thrill of demolishing opponents' fortresses, positions it as a standout choice for strategy gaming enthusiasts. While the potential for more variety in missions exists, the engaging multiplayer dynamics and the creative construction elements make Forts a compelling addition to any gamer's library.

As the indie gaming scene continues to evolve, Forts remains a shining example of how creativity and innovation can thrive in the gaming world. Its enduring appeal serves as a testament to the game's ability to capture the imagination of players, inviting them into a world where architectural prowess meets strategic brilliance. Forts 2017 isn't just a game; it's an ever-expanding battlefield where creativity takes center stage, ensuring its place in the pantheon of indie gaming classics.

TL;DR
The game is a very unique take on RTS and has tons of potential, however, there's no skill-based matchmaking, so it's very hard to learn the game as chances are you're going to die by very experienced players running the same meta loadout as they always do. Anything after the first campaign is just as bad, there seems to be nowhere for casual or new players to go to relax / learn in this game. In the end it's either you figure it out, struggle through pain and torture before figuring it out, or give up entirely. I'm sad it's this way as I love the concept of the game. However, if you love an arms rush and don't mind being punished for not being on the same skill level as most other players, it's a fantastic game and I would recommend it.

Onto the real review, I never thought I'd be writing a negative review about this game. I, (probably) like yourself, have been considering this game for years because of how fun it looks to play from watching YouTube and streams. Let this be a warning - The main aspect of the game, the PvP, is an arms race to 3 end-game weapon combos. So much so most players will ignore all other weapons and race to get to the 3 weapons first. It is extremely hard to get your foot in the door, If you manage to then you'll have a great time! You'll be able to keep pace with most of the player base and things will feel balanced. If however you're too slow you're almost guaranteed death, repeatedly, which only leads to frustration which only hurts your performance more.

However, let's start with the good. The game is very stylized, its appearance is unique and unmistakable. The physics engine is well-made and allows for some pretty crazy shenanigans. The construction mechanics are very different and fun to play with, there's a lot of room for creativity which is sadly underutilized in the main aspect of the game (PvP) but I'll touch more on that later. The construction mechanics are very deep, watching how the bend under stress revealing weak points from previous build mistakes or damage is impressive no matter which side you're on. And of course, it's immensely satisfying to cut off large portions of your enemy, or cause them to explode directly. 
The competitive scene is huge, watching closely matched players go head to head is insanely fun and the games always feel close.

Moving on let's talk PvP. Since there's no skill-based matchmaking it's all about luck. I spent over 10 hours in PvP trying to make it work, I tried various strategies, various builds, but none of them mattered. There's an extreme meta at the moment and the devs seem to ignore it by saying "The weaker weapons are to be used earlier and slowly be replaced as you climb the tech trees." Sadly I disagree with this as if anyone watches competitive players they'll never use weapons outside of the meta unless they're trying to do something funny for a video, or are reliant on teammates following the meta and taking aggression while they meme around. The only exclusion to this is machine guns for anti air, and snipers for punishing build order mistakes. The only other time I've ever seen additional weapons being used seriously is in the pro leagues, and it's all about extremely early aggression, so once again it's a rush and comes down to player speed in construction. To be honest this strategy is so much more painful than the normal meta weapons race as by the time you start taking hits you'll have so little economy you're basically doomed and likely won't have enough resources as you put everything in tech trees to unlock the meta weapons as per usual. The issue is you as a new or even mediocre player can't replicate the strategy because you're simply not as fast as the pro league players.
What about all the other weapons? Surely they can be of some use no matter the meta. If you as a slower, newer player, attempt to use any other weapons than the meta ones you're putting yourself and your team behind, even more so since the enemy team likely knows how to defend against them while getting their own meta weapons up. The meta weapons are as follows; cannon spam, cannon howitzer combo, fire laser and standard laser combo. If you're not using one of these either your teammates are doing so, allowing you to do something interesting for once, or you straight up aren't going to win. Without proper matchmaking it's nearly impossible to hone your skills and build faster as you'll almost always be getting pummeled before you're even close to ready.

Well, how about the singleplayer then?
The first campaign was decent, there's a few levels that are downright awful, taking over 10 attempts (mind you each attempt can be upwards of 10-15 minutes) just to die shy of your goal. But then comes the second campaign, on the second level is where I gave up. It has you starting out in a very small base with little to no resources going up against 3 enemy AI forts that have tons of resources ready to go. I tried this mission over 20 times over various days and never got close. It's as if the devs expected their hyper competitive playerbase to come down and stomp the AI in the campaigns. There is a difficulty slider which you'd think would help with this issue, but it really doesn't seem that way. I played on medium which is required to get the first wave of achievements. For most games I pick medium when entering them for the first time as I'm there for some challenge as that's the only way you'll ever improve. With those ideas in mind, the second campaign is severely unbalanced. Within minutes I'm being pummeled by cannon fire from 3 bases and am so focused on staying alive I can never get weapons out to counterfire as the enemy just upgrades more and more until I'm gone. -- The one time I almost beat the level was by filling the front of my base with snipers and sniping as many of their guns out when they opened doors, which worked for a while on the first base and allowed me to field a meta weapon but by the time I finished off the first I was very damaged and now the other two had clear lines of sight and rapidly blew away my snipers with their meta weapons. Upon asking the community about that campaign it sounds like most of the levels require that strategy, of using snipers to counter weapons the entire time while slowly building yourself up. Why? I came to the campaign to escape the sweaty-ness of multiplayer and have some casual gameplay but it's far from it.

In the end all I did was hurt how I view the game and videos made of it. Going back and watching YouTube of this game all I see are people getting slaughtered by the same 3 meta tactics. I see people like myself who never stood a chance against experienced players, who are going to suffer through loss after loss for the possibility of getting good, but more than likely will fall off early and give up the game. Hopefully, I'll forget the last 24 hours I've put into playing Forts so I can enjoy watching content of the game again. Either way since steam (shockingly) denied my refund request, maybe someday I'll finally get fast enough after throwing my head against the wall for enough hours. We'll see.

From a game design perspective, Forts offers an experience that stands apart from the crowd. Its core game loop is both engaging and meticulously crafted, keeping players invested from one moment to the next.

Where many RTS titles fall into tried-and-true formulas, Forts innovates. Its unique emphasis on construction, combined with a detailed and responsive physics engine, adds depth to each strategic decision. The way structures respond to damage, stress, or even poor design choices is consistent and realistic. There's something immensely satisfying about leveraging the game's physics to craft the perfect strategy, only to watch your opponent's base react precisely as you'd expect when you put your plan into action.

Of course, while the game doesn’t natively support voice chat, pairing it with platforms like Discord elevates the entire experience. With my friends, our shared reactions to cannon attacks and structural collapses have led to countless amazing moments. It’s not just about the game itself, but the communal experience it facilitates.

All in all, if you're seeking a unique RTS that challenges conventional design and rewards creativity, Forts deserves your attention. It promises both challenge and charm in equal measure. Highly recommended!

After more than 250 hours I've moved onto to other games. In no way is that a bad thing, however. I can definitely see this game as a stepping stone into more complicated rts, such as supreme commander or my personal favorite rise of nations. This game while competitive still felt very friendly to me as new player. After some advice from YouTube, I could keep up well with better players, and build complex marvels such as particle accelerators. I did not finish the moonshot DLC campaign, I did not feel interested enough in the story to play-through something I considered much less entertaining than multiplayer. Lobbies when I was starting out were plentiful and had much variety along with a very welcoming community. Therefore even though its time to move on for me at least I will recommend this title to anyone remotely interested in the rts genre. Even at full price, I believe I got good value for the money spent, which is a very rare compliment.

I can't recommend this game enough. This is a masterpiece and so far the most exciting multiplayer game I've ever experienced.

On the surface, I believe Forts would be best described, as real time Worms combined with RTS and physics-based base building. Aside from proper build orders, success in Forts depends on good aim, and an ability to construct a stable base that can both tank the incoming damage, and will not collapse under the weight of the weapons.

Do NOT listen to people claiming that the game hinges on a race towards heavy weapons. The game offers a lot of different tactics, utilizing a wide array of weapons, and the heavy weapons rush is only one of the tactics available (and can actually be easily countered). The game almost feels like fast-paced chess in this regard.
Cannons can be countered by dense defensive layers of struts, or choked by early game aggression.
Dense woodspam can be countered by Buzzsaws (Moonshot DLC).
Buzzsaws and lasers can be countered by armour or energy shields.
Energy shields can be neutralized by EMP launcher and swarm missiles. Both can be countered by anti-air weapons.
And the sniper has the potential of countering just about anything, depending on aim.

There's just so many options that the game never gets stale and maintains the ability to surprise. And that's all before even mentioning mods...

The multitude of creative tactics is best demonstrated by the periodic tournaments ran by the community and presented on video platforms (youtube, twitch).

Single player is a mixed bag, although still very much enjoyable. Campaign is fun, and at times plays like a puzzle solving game.

Unfortunately, this is marred by the awful AI. It is very crude and at times unfun against. The bot is unable to make any decisions in regards to building, and will always build the same pre-scripted fort, never improvises, always does the same thing. Once you saw an AI fort once on a given map, you saw it all. You can repeatedly shoot the same weapon spot with an armour-piercing sniper, and are guaranteed that the bot will keep placing this weapon in that spot [b]always[/b], every single game. Granted, the game has the capability to hold multiple bot fort designs for a given map (and you can even design your own), however this feature is rarely explored, and poorly explained.

On the other hand - to compensate for its general stupidity - the bot has been given an ability to cheat. [b]It can see through walls and always knows where your weapons are[/b]. There's no point in concealing your weapons and devices, as simply not placing a door to protect the weapon (something that is an acceptable tactic against a real human player) makes it guaranteed to be sniped. Using the Phantom commander against the AI is completely pointless. This - coupled with the godly aim of the bot, as well as its inability to understand and play the capture the point mode, makes AI matches a subpar experience, and at times frustrating even.

With all that said, I highly encourage you to play this gem. Never before have I had so much fun with a multiplayer game as when I've played Forts with my friends.

Just need to add - I highly recommend getting the Moonshot DLC. It is pretty much essential in multiplayer. That said, the game allows you to access the DLC content without owning it, as long as you play in a multiplayer lobby hosted by someone who does own the DLC.

decent little rts with short learning curve.  It suffers from the same issue as any rts where build order and apm are king. That said, my experience is that the online play outside of the top 50-100 players is mostly goofing around without a hint of competitive play.  The upside to this is that if you want to play a highly competitive  game(provided  you  can find other like-minded players online) you certainly can.  Additionally if you want to mess arround, maybe add mods and watch the pretty explosions, that's  an  easy thing to accomplish.  Unfortunately the game is pretty shallow so that's where the options end for this.   

All that said the gameplay loop can be pretty fun for a while, online play and mods can extend that while for a bit.  Compared to more complex RTS games it may leave something to be desired for someone used to them, but I also think the simplicity of this game makes it much more accessible to the casual player as it only takes a few games to figure out the build orders and mechanics of the game.  I would strongly suggest picking up the moonshot and high seas dlc with the base game if you decide to buy, as if the game with the dlc feels pretty shallow after a bit, the base game on it's own is significantly more so.

I'll make a disclaimer here saying that I loved Worms as a kid.

Onto the review: This game combines ideas from strategy RTS, Worms and Poly Bridge. It has physics based base building with connectors and tiles like Poly Bridge. Inside of those bases you have a Reactor which you must protect. You do that by killing the enemy player (or AI), before they do the same to you.

Unlike Worms there is no turn-based combat, thus this game strongly rewards high APM. This coupled with the fact that there is resource management is what characterizes it as being akin to an RTS.

This comes with its own issues, as it introduces a higher skill floor and ceiling when playing against other people. Should you plan to only play this with a friend, this won't matter as you will have a blast either way. Should you plan to play this alone against others, be aware that there is a "right" way to play this game. There is a meta.

All of that being said, it's a very fun game, and I'd recommend it for anyone looking for a fun time with friends.

On the technical level it works fine, it doesn't  feels at all like an unfinished game although there could be some improvement here and there.
For instance it is a little annoying to find the right lobby for you: the game lacks a matchmaking system and it doesn't let you see the game options before you enter a lobby.

Game-play wise it gives me mixed feeling: I find it visually very compelling, bombarding my foes and seeing my shots  break their base feels at the same time evocative and intuitive, it perfectly convey the idea of a fight to me.
On the other hand i am often disappointed by the repetitiveness of many matches. There are indeed many structural elements which limit the strategic dept of the game; let me point out a few of them.
1) the average game length is 10-15 minutes.The game is indeed very fast paced and requires a great ability at micromanaging.This doesn't leave room for thinking and adapting you're plan. 
2)there is no depth, literally.The 2 dimension limitation is worsened even further by the small distance by which you are allowed to move in most maps. Little space=little options
3)the game is unforgiving , many games finishes with the first shot fired, and in general there won't be a come back from the loosing player.Aggressive strategies are usually favoured. This is somewhat discouraging if you are trying a new strategy.Also there are no "secondary objectives" , you never have to decide your priority target(there always is only one);this results again in a lower depth.
4)the general small number of variables affecting each game, and the small time you have to think, forces you to always use the same layout for your fort, further reducing the number of variable. I also must mention that there are not that many viable options for how to build your fort. The only thing you really have to decide is what weapon do you want to use(which is at least something).
5)The game is balanced for competitive 1v1, most of the game you'll find are casual 4v4.Many weapons looses relevance in 4v4, and in general your actions will be diluted inside your team's, to the point you don't even understand if you are playing well or not.
In non competitive 1v1 many options looses relevance because the players do not have the proper micro skill.


Despite all that if you dig trough all this and reach the bottom of Pandora's box you will find some hope for this game to achieve greatness in the form of a sandbox. The devs have made it extremely easy to exchange custom made maps and also custom made mods.This could potentially bring an infinite number of options to the game. Unfortunately most modded  games are either too messed up to be playable or too close to the original game to be note worthy.There are exceptions and i manage to find occasionally some balanced games which get me thinking on new creative ways to play.


I also should mention that there are 2 dlcs (which you are generously allowed to play even without buying).The dlcs are good and definitely improve the game.


Last and least i'd like to address the campaign: it's nice but it's not the reason why you want to buy the game,
You get to build forts and kill russians... what more could you ask for.

Unless you got blown up first.  
There are also hero units too.  Some are more helpful than others, but it does make playing with different heroes selected more interesting due to the abilities, both passive and activated.

    I should mention beforehand that I typically enjoy this game but find myself complaining or blaming the game by the end of it all. Every man has their breaking point; the following is the result of my breaking point, when I lost a match I shouldn't have and immediately opened the store page to write a NASTY review. Again I like this game but man it feels unbalanced.

    This game has two GAPING flaws (GAPING) that ruin this game for me, those two being the doodoo micromanagement and exponential failure loop.

    In terms of the doodoo micromanagement, it takes form whenever your structures are destroyed because what follows is a fast-paced rebuilding spree that is NOT fun. This involves rebuilding your structures as they were before and ensuring the new structures will actually be compatible with devices and weapons-- both of which taking time away from launching a counter-attack.
    This is ANNOYING (!!) and it's entirely because devices and weapons require strict placement and planning, meaning your structures MUST be flat and they must NOT be sloped. This isn't fun and is in direct opposition with the physics engine, which sometimes allows for chaotic architecture that serves as a detriment. How cool would it be to have this Frankenstein base make an epic comeback?
    A wicked solution would be separating unit rotation and positioning entirely. This removes the strategy that comes with planning a base but the result is far better.

    The next GAPING (GAPING) issue is the EXPONENTIAL FAILURE LOOP™!! This is a term I coined (that's right..) for two systems in Forts that reward losing with more losing. There could be more, and probably are, but these two are the perpetrators I recall being the most anti-fun.
            - Repairing damaged structures drains metal per second. Damaged structures are the result of being attacked, so being attacked results in losing materials that could be spent building devices and weapons or launching a counter-attack. This is a penalty for losing. Why? :_(
            - The previously mentioned problem also applies here, in that time is wasted when rebuilding after being attacked. Time wasted with sucky building is the result of being attacked, so being attacked results in wasted time that could be spent doing yada yada... This is a penalty for losing. Why? :__(

    There was also this common complaint that most games devolve into a "race to the big guns," but recent hours proved this wasn't the case. I'm assuming the developers fixed this, so GOOD ON THEM. Another issue that can ruin games and MUST be fixed is the unreliable anti-air, in which sometimes my machine-guns/mini-guns/shotguns do nothing to counter air attacks. In my 40 hours of playing I cannot for the life of all creatures on this Earth figure out what causes this, which says something about the game maybe.

    I'll go ahead and list my favorite aspects to this game while I'm at it.
            - The physics engine is great fun.
            - Mods are nice. Glad support is here.
            - I love when strategy is utilized in this game, like timing sniper shots, faking out anti-air, or even using mini-guns to decimate enemy units.
            - Naturally this game is real satisfying. It's always nice using the big cannon or plasma beam to shred through enemy structures like CURD hahaha. There's also some fun to suffering and catastrophic failure, but erm not if you feel it was unjustified.
            - Aesthetics are nice. I enjoy the visuals and music, and the art style is particularly fantastic.

    Ultimately I DO enjoy this game but it's a frustrating experience that could be so much more. Whether the fun is worth the pain is your call boss.

This game could be great, but its terrible because of a few things that just make it annoying rather than fun. 

First, the physics around wall building is annoying. Everything bounces, and just when you're trying to drop something in that confined spot, it smacks into a wall and boom, there goes your wall...again. Try attaching two walls with cross braces, and they bounce in and out of scope (distance) making it luck if you manage to pin those two long braces together. 

Next up is firing arcs - i completely hate these. You have to play part of the game in close to select  your firing unit and get it to fire (you have to click in a very specific arc, in real time), but you are trying to hit something far away so you are constantly zooming in and out to try to figure out the arc. It just makes it more of a mouse zoom wheel challenge than a fun experience. 

And lastly are the machine guns. I've read a ton of articles on taking out missiles with gunners, but upgrade, don't upgrade -- its irrelevant -- they don't autofire. And so you try to take them out manually, but by the time you see the missiles heading toward you, you frantically click your control group, then find the mouse, then position it into the firing arc, and watch as your blast doors crawl open... just in time to see all the missiles impact your base. Its just plain ridiculous. 

I really wanted to like this game, and enjoy building and RTS games more than any other genre, but its just completely frustrating and not fun.

In Forts you build forts, gather resources, improve your fort and add guns and then shoot at the enemy fort till it blows up. Its a pretty simple idea. And it works really well.

+Building a fort is tons of fun.
+Tons of weapons. Machine guns that can be upgraded into miniguns, snipers that can be upgraded into AP snipers, incendiary mortars that can be upgraded into heavy mortars and the two most fun weapons: The cannon and the laser beam. These things are the last weapons you can build in a match, they take a long time to build, cost a lot of resources,
firing them costs a lot too just like building them does and they take a long time to reload but fuck me they hit like a dumpster truck.
+3 factions. Basically America, Russia and China.
+You can use the weapons yourself. You don't just place them and watch them fire at each other. You have to take control of a weapon, aim it and fire it yourself and firing some of the bigger guns, firing the mortars using angles and speed, firing the snipers and hitting someone hiding behind a metal door its just really fun. The only weapon that can do its own thing
automatically is the machine gun. If you wanna shoot at the enemy you take control of the machine gun and shoot it. If you don't touch the machine guns and just let them do their own thing then, if they can, they will shoot at incoming mortar shells or swarm missiles. Having a wall of automatic machine guns that just blow up every incoming mortar shell is so cool to see.
+You can group 3 weapons and fire them all at once. Firing 3 mortars at once or firing 3 miniguns at once is fun. Firing 3 cannons at once is an incredible feeling.
+3 campaings with around 9 missions each. The first camping is the Americans its basically a training. The 2nd campaing is the Russians and the last campaing is the Chinese. The missions get harder and longer as you progress through the game. There are different areas too from the Middle East to Europe and lastly to Siberia. 3 factions, 3 campaings, 3 regions with 3 missions for each region.
+The destruction in this game is perfect. Seeing a fort crumble in on itself is so much fun. Finding a weak spot or repeatedly shooting the same area over and over again to create a weak spot and then destroying that last single piece on the enemy fort that is holding the entire structure together and watching it all fall apart is so cool to see. Of course the same happens to you too.

-I feel like the training missions could be better. The game teached me basically everything except how to build a stable, future-proof fort. Which is a really important part of this game building forts. I had to learn this myself with trial and error and i still have no clue how to make a future proof fort. I can make somewhat stable forts but none of them can be improved if you do try to change something and improve the fort then the entire building will collapse in on itself. I'm just a bad architect i guess.
-The game does get boring after a while.

The game requires that you work with your team constructing a "Fort" or even several of your own, and arming it with weapons and defensive measures to try and destroy the enemy's "Reactor", the main core of a Fort.
Weapons include Machine Guns, Heavy Artillery, and Cannons, along with an entire host of other things to tear the enemy apart with.
Forts supports mods that add an entirely new level of depth to the game including things like Flying Forts, Endo's Arsenal, among others that can give the game mountains of re-play value.

All in all, this game is well worth the price point, and i recommend that you give it a shot.

Easily one of my all-time favorite games; if you're not enjoying it, it's either you aren't into this genre, or you don't understand how to play. 

Forts has been even more balanced than ever with the new commander updates which revamped most commanders, making Pinchfist (a rush commander) not the default choice for 1v1s and 2v2s anymore, and each commander (except that poor bastard Moonshine) more fun to play. Also real kind for the devs not to make 'Moonshot DLC' exclusive lobbies. (please don't get any ideas)

As a whole, Forts has never been in a better state; a more vibrant community, balanced weapons, and a decent learning curve for newer players to join (not everyone is a tryhard). Here are some good and bad things I feel exist as of this post:

Positive:
-(Ridiculously) High skill ceiling

-Matchmaking is quick, compared to 2 years ago;

-Game feels more balanced 

-Moonshot DLC is well worth its price, for all the new content added

-Wide variety of content from the Workshop to spice up gameplay

-Great to play with friends

-Pinchfist


Negative: (bit of nitpicky stuff here)
-The original campaign: 
As a whole, I feel that it is a decent tutorial to the game, but it does get somewhat stale in comparison with moonshot. Still, that is to be expected from the on-release campaign of OG forts. 

The bigger issue I feel exists with it, is that firstly, it doesn't introduce new players to commanders; a huge driving force in Multiplayer. Secondly, its objective-based approach is rarely applicational to Multiplayer. 

The heart and soul of Forts lies in its multiplayer, no doubt, and new players fresh form the campaign might be worse off in lobbies, as there is no guiding force for them, except for 'bash your opponent with da big gun'.

From a story standpoint, the campaign is great, and the dialogue keeps it entertaining, but its negatives might overshadow the true gold of the game; Multiplayer.

-No in-game menu options (let me control the audio whilst in a match ffs)

-Report system is kinda wack (needs fixing)

-Player names with question marks and lists of numbers: Probably from another country where the language isn't supported by Forts. Tbh you can't really fix this one. If yall see a dude with this kind of name, except not to speak the same language (or understand them at all)

-Moonshine.

Overall, I give WW3 Simulator 10 out of 10 Howitzers. It's a great game once you really get into it, and will definitely entertain you through quarantine. The multiplayer is... well it's solidified itself into a more or less diehard fanbase. There's no better description than "Given the opportunity, players will optimize the fun out of games". That's the multiplayer of this game.

There's also the saying that "Host only cares about his win" because most Lobby Hosts will virtually never address team imbalance if they win. Only "new-ish" players will sometimes host lobbies and care about more than just winning.

Mods just make it exponentially worse because they will add a bunch of interesting things but they will also inevitably add things that are inherently unbalance or just blatantly overpowered. And players will flock to said weapons because "Fun" doesn't win games the same way as "One-Hit-Kills" or "No Counter" weapons do. 

What makes it worse is that generally speaking the people who host modded lobbies typically already know exactly what they are going to do. And alot of the time that just means they are going to do something they believe is going to win fast or easily.

There's plenty of settings and a campaign mode. There's not much else to say, what you see is what you get. 3/5 recommended.

This is a very fun physics based game where you can utterly destroy the AI, or other players in the multiplayer. Overall, the game is very smooth and the campaign is challenging. I also have purchased the Moonshot DLC, which adds more weapons and a second campaign which are both very fun and add even more to the game. With both the base game, and the DLC, there is also the limitless steam workshop. Once I got bored with the base weapons and maps, I quickly found some popular mods and my whole game was changed. So, final view; If you like RTS games, and you want to have a nice, fun game with explosion, this game is for you. However, if you are more into turn based games, and games where you are less micromanaging things and more action, this probably isn't the game for you. I hope that this review was helpful because I really enjoy this game, and I hope others will too.
